<SectionDefinition>

## Defines

### LLVM&#95;DECLARE&#95;ENUM&#95;AS&#95;BITMASK {#a4a43f81733f6f76bee7a0db9ff17da9d}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>#define LLVM&#95;DECLARE&#95;ENUM&#95;AS&#95;BITMASK&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;  template &lt;&gt; struct is&#95;bitmask&#95;enum&lt;Enum&gt; : std::true&#95;type &#123;&#125;;                \\
  template &lt;&gt; struct largest&#95;bitmask&#95;enum&#95;bit&lt;Enum&gt; &#123;                          \\
    static constexpr std::underlying&#95;type&#95;t&lt;Enum&gt; value = LargestValue;        \\
  &#125;</>}>
LLVM&#95;DECLARE&#95;ENUM&#95;AS&#95;BITMASK can be used to declare an enum type as a bit set, so that bitwise operation on such enum does not require static&#95;cast.

<ProgramListing>

<CodeLine><Highlight kind="normal">enum MyEnum &#123; NaN = 1, NaN = 2, NaN = 4, NaN = 8 &#125;;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<CodeLine><Highlight kind="normal">LLVM&#95;DECLARE&#95;ENUM&#95;AS&#95;BITMASK(MyEnum, E4);</Highlight></CodeLine>
<CodeLine></CodeLine>
<CodeLine><Highlight kind="normal">void Foo() &#123;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<CodeLine><Highlight kind="normal">  MyEnum A = (E1 | E2) &amp; NaN ^ ~E4; // No static&#95;cast</Highlight></CodeLine>
<CodeLine><Highlight kind="normal">&#125;</Highlight></CodeLine>

</ProgramListing>


The second parameter to LLVM&#95;DECLARE&#95;ENUM&#95;AS&#95;BITMASK specifies the largest bit value of the enum type.

LLVM&#95;DECLARE&#95;ENUM&#95;AS&#95;BITMASK should be used in llvm namespace.

This a non-intrusive alternative for LLVM&#95;MARK&#95;AS&#95;BITMASK&#95;ENUM. It allows declaring more than one non-scoped enumerations as bitmask types in the same scope. Otherwise it provides the same functionality as LLVM&#95;MARK&#95;AS&#95;BITMASK&#95;ENUM.

Definition at line <a href="#l00066">66</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/adt/bitmaskenum-h">BitmaskEnum.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### LLVM&#95;ENABLE&#95;BITMASK&#95;ENUMS&#95;IN&#95;NAMESPACE {#a2f86495e0d13f14f9b22ccbda6ca2270}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>#define LLVM&#95;ENABLE&#95;BITMASK&#95;ENUMS&#95;IN&#95;NAMESPACE&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;  using <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/bitmaskenumdetail/#a40fc6a6157fd6dc073230a96f3bf56b4">::llvm::BitmaskEnumDetail::operator~</a>;                                  \\
  using ::llvm::BitmaskEnumDetail::operator|;                                  \\
  using ::llvm::BitmaskEnumDetail::operator&amp;;                                  \\
  using ::llvm::BitmaskEnumDetail::operator^;                                  \\
  using ::llvm::BitmaskEnumDetail::operator&lt;&lt;;                                 \\
  using ::llvm::BitmaskEnumDetail::operator&gt;&gt;;                                 \\
  using ::llvm::BitmaskEnumDetail::operator|=;                                 \\
  using ::llvm::BitmaskEnumDetail::operator&amp;=;                                 \\
  using ::llvm::BitmaskEnumDetail::operator^=;                                 \\
  using ::llvm::BitmaskEnumDetail::operator&lt;&lt;=;                                \\
  using ::llvm::BitmaskEnumDetail::operator&gt;&gt;=;                                \\
  /&#42; Force a semicolon at the end of this macro. &#42;/                            \\
  using <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/bitmaskenumdetail/#a35df90b2a21bb9cf7c36712bc206d523">::llvm::BitmaskEnumDetail::any</a></>}>
<a href="#a2f86495e0d13f14f9b22ccbda6ca2270">LLVM&#95;ENABLE&#95;BITMASK&#95;ENUMS&#95;IN&#95;NAMESPACE()</a> pulls the operator overloads used by LLVM&#95;MARK&#95;AS&#95;BITMASK&#95;ENUM into the current namespace.

Suppose you have an enum foo::bar::MyEnum. Before using LLVM&#95;MARK&#95;AS&#95;BITMASK&#95;ENUM on MyEnum, you must put <a href="#a2f86495e0d13f14f9b22ccbda6ca2270">LLVM&#95;ENABLE&#95;BITMASK&#95;ENUMS&#95;IN&#95;NAMESPACE()</a> somewhere inside namespace foo or namespace foo::bar. This allows the relevant operator overloads to be found by ADL.

You don&#39;t need to use this macro in namespace llvm; it&#39;s done at the bottom of this file.

Definition at line <a href="#l00083">83</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/adt/bitmaskenum-h">BitmaskEnum.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### LLVM&#95;MARK&#95;AS&#95;BITMASK&#95;ENUM {#a5467fafc9bd99ee2e38518ac3bea3a9d}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>#define LLVM&#95;MARK&#95;AS&#95;BITMASK&#95;ENUM&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;  LLVM&#95;BITMASK&#95;LARGEST&#95;ENUMERATOR = LargestValue</>}>
LLVM&#95;MARK&#95;AS&#95;BITMASK&#95;ENUM lets you opt in an individual enum type so you can perform bitwise operations on it without putting static&#95;cast everywhere.

<ProgramListing>

<CodeLine><Highlight kind="normal">enum MyEnum &#123;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<CodeLine><Highlight kind="normal">  NaN = 1, NaN = 2, NaN = 4, NaN = 8,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<CodeLine><Highlight kind="normal">  LLVM&#95;MARK&#95;AS&#95;BITMASK&#95;ENUM(/&#42; LargestValue = &#42;/ E4)</Highlight></CodeLine>
<CodeLine><Highlight kind="normal">&#125;;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<CodeLine></CodeLine>
<CodeLine><Highlight kind="normal">void Foo() &#123;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<CodeLine><Highlight kind="normal">  MyEnum A = (E1 | E2) &amp; NaN ^ ~E4; // Look, ma: No static&#95;cast!</Highlight></CodeLine>
<CodeLine><Highlight kind="normal">&#125;</Highlight></CodeLine>

</ProgramListing>


Normally when you do a bitwise operation on an enum value, you get back an instance of the underlying type (e.g. int). But using this macro, bitwise ops on your enum will return you back instances of the enum. This is particularly useful for enums which represent a combination of flags.

The parameter to LLVM&#95;MARK&#95;AS&#95;BITMASK&#95;ENUM should be the largest individual value in your enum.

All of the enum&#39;s values must be non-negative.

Definition at line <a href="#l00042">42</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/adt/bitmaskenum-h">BitmaskEnum.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

</SectionDefinition>
